Which MATLAB code would you use to generate the appropriate DTMF signal to represent telephone key number 5? And this is another way.
The meaning of "negative frequency" in a Fourier series is:
Negative frequencies represent those frequencies that, when measured from a plot, look like they are below ½fs.
A negative Fourier series component of a signal represents the imaginary part of the signal.

A negative Fourier series component represents a term in the Fourier series sum that has a negative value of frequency in the complex exponential. When it is added to a positive (absolute value) frequency component with the same amplitude, a real signal will result.
A negative frequency in the Fourier series represents the same signal component as the positive (absolute value) frequency, but with a negative amplitude.
Definition: A lowpass filter with magnitude response that supresses high frequencies of the input.

In signal processing, the purpose of the z-domain is to transform time-domain signals (x[n])
into another domain where signals can be representd by polynomials and systems can be
represented by rational functions. This transformation greatly simplifies signal manipulation
and filter design.

The is a SPECIAL warning for this lab. You will probably use the freqz.m function during this lab. However, this function has a STRANGE behavior if you use it to evaluate the frequency response at ONE frequency only. The work around is to invoke freqz.m with two frequencies, even if you only want one. For example, you could repeat the frequency of interest to make a two-element vector of frequencies.

A student modulates a sinusoidal carrier xc=cos(2*pi*2000*t) with the following chirp signal: 
x1 = cos(2*pi*400*t + 35*cos(2*pi*10*t))
Which of the following most accurately describes the shape of the spectrogram of the modulated signal?

NOTE: like the AM Lab Warm-up, the spectrogram will exhibit sinusoidal shapes.
(Assume a sampling rate of 44.1kHz, and a spectrogram display that only shows positive frequencies)
One sinusoidal shape centered at 2000 Hz that varies plus or minus 350 Hz, i.e., between 1650 Hz and 2350 Hz.
Two sinusoidal shapes: one centered at 2400 Hz varying plus or minus 35 Hz; the other centered at 1600 Hz varying plus or minus 35 Hz.
Two sinusoidal shapes: one centered at 2400 Hz varying plus or minus 350 Hz; the other centered at 1600 Hz varying plus or minus 350 Hz.
One sinusoidal shape centered at 400 Hz that varies between 365 Hz and 435 Hz.
A straight line at 2000 Hz plus two sinusoidal shapes: one centered at 2750 Hz varying plus or minus 10 Hz; the other centered at 1250 Hz varying plus or minus 10 Hz.

Given a VonHann filter defined by following code: 
M = 50; nn = 0:M;
VH = (sin(pi*nn/M)).^2;                  %-- VonHann window
wc = 0.3*pi;
sincwc = sin(wc*(nn-M/2))./(pi*(nn-M/2)); %-- sinc function
sincwc(M/2 + 1) = wc/pi;                  %-- fix divide by zero
bb = sincwc.*VH;                          %-- Filter Coefficients
Choose all correct answers from the following choices, which will evaluate the frequency response of the filter at frequency equal to π.

A stable system is one whose output does not blow up (that is, y[n] is bounded when x[n] is bounded). Therefore, the impulse response of a stable system must not blow up.
In general, what can be said about the placement of the poles to guarantee stability?
If necessary, use PeZ to generate examples with multiple poles
They must be in complex conjugate pairs.
They must ALL be inside the unit circle.
They must ALL be outside the unit circle.
Most (but not all) of the poles must be inside the unit circle.
Half of them must be inside the unit circle, and the other half must be outside. If there are an odd number of poles, they must be on the unit circle.

Refer to the following function, which is similar to that used in lab 4:

function tone = note(keynum,dur)
% Returns a single sinusoid with the key and duration specified
fs = 11025;
tt = 0:1/fs:dur;
f0 = 440*2^((keynum-49)/12);
tone = cos(2*pi*f0*tt);
A student wants to modify the function so that the tone created by this function has TWO frequency components. The new tone should be the sum of two sinusoids, one of which is the frequency for the key number, and the other of which has a frequency 1.5 times higher. The amplitudes (and phases) can be the same. Which one of the following is a correct modification that will accomplish this task?

Replace the last line of note() with
tone = cos(2*pi*(3/2)*f0*tt);

Replace the last line of note() with
tone = cos(2*pi*f0*([1 3/2]')*tt);

Replace the function CALL (in the main program) with
xx(n1:n2) = xx(n1:n2) + note([f 3/2*f],dur);

Replace the last line of note() with
tone = cos(2*pi*f0*tt) + cos(2*pi*3/2*f0*tt)

Insert the following line before the last line of note()
f0 = f0 + 3/2*f0;
